issues.description: The problem statement / UML specifies a Stock method named addToStockIngredients(StockIngredient) (used by the solution SealSaloon.acceptSupplyDelivery), but the template Stock class provides a method named addItem(StockIngredient) instead. This name mismatch is structural: students following the UML/instructions will try to call addToStockIngredients (or implement SealSaloon using that name) but the starter template does not define it, causing compile errors or confusion about which method to use.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the method names consistent. Either rename the template's addItem(StockIngredient) to addToStockIngredients(StockIngredient), or update the problem statement/UML to reference addItem. Ensure the Stock API in the template matches the API used in the reference solution and the UML so students can implement SealSaloon without naming conflicts.

issues.description: The problem statement's class diagram and the solution implementation use a Stock method named addToStockIngredients(StockIngredient), but the template repository defines this operation as addItem(StockIngredient). This inconsistent identifier for the same conceptual operation (adding a StockIngredient into the Stock) can confuse students: they will look for addToStockIngredients as shown in the diagram and in the solution, but the starter code exposes addItem instead. This mismatch may cause students to (a) spend time searching for the expected method, (b) accidentally implement a duplicate method, or (c) change the wrong place, introducing extraneous cognitive load unrelated to the exercise learning goals.
issues.suggested_fix: Rename the template method addItem(StockIngredient) to addToStockIngredients(StockIngredient) so the starter code matches the problem diagram and the solution. Alternatively, update the problem statement/diagram and solution to use addItem consistently. Prefer aligning the template to the diagram/solution to avoid student confusion.
